questions.stem: Where should footnote numbers be placed in text?

options.label: Only at the end of paragraphs

questions.rationale: Footnote numbers should be placed after punctuation marks, not before them.

questions.stem: Complete this footnote citation: ¹ Department of Justice Canada, __________ (Ottawa: Government of Canada, 2023), __________.
questions.rationale: Government document footnotes include: Department, Title in italics, (Location: Publisher, Year), page.

questions.stem: Click on the incorrectly formatted footnote number:
questions.text: The policy was implemented in 2023¹, resulting in significant changes.² However, critics argued³ that the timeline was problematic.

errors.reason: Footnote number should come after punctuation, not before

questions.rationale: Footnote numbers should be placed after punctuation marks and at the end of sentences.

questions.stem: Match the footnote type with its purpose:

pairs.right: Provide English versions of foreign terms

questions.rationale: Different types of footnotes serve different purposes in documentation.

questions.stem: What is the correct format for citing Canadian legislation in a footnote?
questions.rationale: Canadian legislation citations include the title, statute series, year, and chapter number.

questions.stem: What is the difference between a bibliography and a reference list?

options.label: Bibliography includes all sources consulted; references include only cited sources
Bibliography is for books only; references are for articles
Bibliography is alphabetical; references are chronological

questions.rationale: A bibliography includes all sources consulted during research, while a reference list includes only sources actually cited in the text.

questions.stem: Complete this bibliography entry: Smith, John. __________. Toronto: University of Toronto Press, 2023.
questions.rationale: Book titles in bibliographies should be italicized and follow the author name.

questions.stem: Match the source type with its bibliography format:

pairs.right: Author. "Title." Journal Volume, no. Issue (Year): pages.

questions.rationale: Different source types require different bibliography formats.

questions.stem: Click on the formatting error in this bibliography entry:
questions.text: Wilson, Sarah. Policy Implementation Challenges. Canadian Public Administration 67, no. 2 (2023): 145-162.

errors.reason: Article titles should be in quotation marks

questions.rationale: Article titles use quotation marks, journal names are italicized.

questions.stem: How should entries with no author be alphabetized in a bibliography?

options.label: At the end of the bibliography

questions.rationale: Sources with no author are alphabetized by title, ignoring initial articles.

questions.stem: When must you cite a source?

options.label: For direct quotations, paraphrased ideas, and statistical data
Only when the source requests it

questions.rationale: Citations are required for direct quotations, paraphrased ideas, statistical data, specific facts, and expert opinions.

questions.stem: Complete this APA-style in-text citation: The study found significant improvements __________, demonstrating policy effectiveness.
questions.rationale: APA in-text citations include author's last name and publication year in parentheses.

questions.stem: Match the citation style with its in-text format:
questions.rationale: Different citation systems use different in-text reference formats.

questions.stem: Click on the citation error:
questions.text: According to the Privacy Act, R.S.C. 1985, c. P-21, personal information must be protected (s. 7).
questions.rationale: Legal citations require proper punctuation: R.S.C., 1985 (with comma).

questions.stem: What information is essential for citing online government sources?

options.label: Author, title, date, URL, and access date

questions.rationale: Online government sources require complete citation information including access dates due to frequent changes.

questions.stem: What is the primary purpose of an index?

options.label: To list all the sources used
To provide alphabetical access to topics and concepts
To replace the table of contents

questions.rationale: Indexes provide alphabetical access to topics, names, and concepts within a document.

questions.stem: Complete this index entry: Government departments __________ Environment and Climate Change Canada, 34 __________ Health Canada, 56, 78
questions.rationale: Subentries in indexes are indented under main entries to show hierarchy.

questions.stem: Match the index entry type with its example:

pairs.right: Public servants. See also Civil service

questions.rationale: Different types of index entries serve different organizational purposes.

questions.stem: How should page ranges be shown in index entries?
questions.rationale: Page ranges in indexes use hyphens: 23-27, not individual page numbers or 'pp.' abbreviations.

questions.stem: Click on the alphabetization error in this index:
questions.text:
Employment insurance, 45
Environment protection, 67
EI benefits, 23
Health services, 89

errors.reason: EI should be alphabetized as 'Employment Insurance' and placed appropriately

questions.rationale: Abbreviations should be alphabetized as if spelled out or cross-referenced to the full form.

questions.stem: Why are access dates important for electronic sources?

options.label: They show when the document was created
Electronic sources can change or disappear without notice
They are required by copyright law

questions.rationale: Access dates are crucial because electronic sources can be updated, moved, or removed without notice.

questions.stem: Complete this electronic source citation: Health Canada. "Vaccine Safety." Canada.ca. Last modified March 5, 2024. __________ March 10, 2024. __________.
questions.rationale: Electronic citations need access dates and complete URLs for verification.

questions.stem: Match the electronic source type with citation considerations:

pairs.right: Include database name and access method

questions.rationale: Different electronic sources have specific citation requirements and challenges.

questions.stem: Click on the incomplete element in this electronic citation:
questions.text: Statistics Canada. "Labour Force Survey, February 2024." The Daily. March 8, 2024. https://www150.statcan.gc.ca/n1/daily-quotidien/240308/dq240308a-eng.htm.
questions.rationale: Electronic source citations must include the date when the source was accessed.

questions.stem: What is the best practice for ensuring long-term access to electronic sources?

options.label: Use permalink URLs and consider web archiving

questions.rationale: Permanent URLs and web archives help ensure long-term access to electronic sources.
